com/patterns/sources/susanna-vogts-ravelry-store ~ 4 ~ daisy crochet pattern by susanna finishing & stem assembly for a full stem put a drop of hot glue on the tip of the dowel and insert into the hole you left in the starting round of the calix you can angle the flower head if you want or attach it straight up just decide before the glue sets to start the wrap i pull a length of yarn from the skein but don t cut it tie a sort of half-knot the first step just wrapped around itself once add a dab of glue where the calix meets the stem then quickly push the yarn all the way up to meet the calix begin wrapping so there are no gaps left capturing the starting end of the yarn under your wraps and snipping it after a few rounds using occasional dabs of glue as you go wrap yarn around the dowel scrunching the yarn strands into each other as you move down the dowel as well when you reach the end of the dowel secure the yarn at the bottom with another drop of glue and then cut the yarn attach leaves see note above under the leaf instructions you ll probably need to re-shape the petals one last time once you ve finished all of the sewing and assembling https //www ravelry com/patterns/sources/susanna-vogts-ravelry-store ~ 5 ~ daisy crochet pattern by susanna alternate options the daisy family is huge and includes many many variations including sunflowers crysanthemums black-eyed susans etc i tried to make this match the common daisy most people picture most similar in shape to a shasta daisy or an english daisy you can adjust it in a few ways many daisy varieties have multiple layers of petals and others have only one you can omit one of the blo rounds of the center disc to make a single-layer of petals example photo taken after my dog got a hold of it for a chew toy but it regained its shape pretty acceptably https //www ravelry com/patterns/sources/susanna-vogts-ravelry-store i designed the center disc to puff up quite a bit again this varies among
